questions.question: What is the special ability of the title character in "The Martian"?

choices.answer: It can recreate itself to look like someone who is dead.
It can see the future of anyone by looking in his/her eyes.
It can heal the sick with its blood.
It can read another's thoughts telepathically.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT happen in "The Martian"?

choices.answer: Nomland kills himself after seeing the man he had killed years ago.
The Martian chooses to abandon Tom's persona so he can be Lavinia Spaulding
Spauldings believe their daughter Lavinia is alive after having drowned.
Tom dies after being bombarded by the townspeople's memories/longings.

questions.question: In "Sound of Thunder," hunters are allowed to kill dinosaurs with red paint because those animals . . .

choices.answer: ...are not real.
...have only one brain.
...are easiest to kill.
...are going to die anyway.

questions.question: What leads Eckles to step off the path in "The Sound of Thunder"?

choices.answer: necessity
panic
anger
curiosity

questions.question: What does the "sound of thunder" in the title hint at?

choices.answer: Safari guide shoots the man who stepped off the path.
The world comes to an end.
The butterfly is found on Eckles' boot.
The man who stepped off the path kills himself.

questions.question: Why is no one home in "There Will Come Soft Rains"?

choices.answer: The house is too expensive to upgrade so they moved out.
Everyone has been killed.
The house is for sale.
Everyone is at work or school

questions.question: Based on the story "There Will Come Soft Rains," we can guess that Bradbury would be in favor of . . .

choices.answer: increasing our stockpile of nuclear weapons.
nuclear disarmament.
automating all houses.
people doing their own housework.

questions.question: The setting of "There Will Come Soft Rains" suggests that human beings

choices.answer: have evolved into androids.
view nature as distasteful.
are dependent on machines.
have no free choice.

questions.question: Define Metaphor.

choices.answer: comparison using "like" or "as"
comparison NOT using "like" or "as"
a word that mimics the actual sound of something
giving human characteristics to something not human

questions.question: Define simile.

choices.answer: giving human characteristics to something not human
comparison using "like" or "as"
comparison NOT using "like" or "as"
a word that mimics the actual sound of something

questions.question: Define personification.

choices.answer: a word that mimics the actual sound of something
giving human characteristics to something not human
comparison NOT using "like" or "as"
comparison NOT using "like" or "as"

questions.question: Define Onomatopoeia.

choices.answer: comparison NOT using "like" or "as"
giving human characteristics to something not human
comparison using "like" or "as"
a word that mimics the actual sound of something

questions.question: Define Theme in a piece of literature.

choices.answer: The subject
The recurring melody
The universal truth/lesson/message
The point of highest action

questions.question: What is the literary term for hints at what is to come in a story?

choices.answer: foreshadowing
resolution
anticipation
clues

questions.question: Define irony.

choices.answer: hints at what is to come in the story
an implied comparison between two unlike subjects
a twist at the climax
difference between what youâ€™d expect to happen and what actually occurs.

questions.question: What is the Butterfly Effect in connection to possible Time Travel?

choices.answer: Killing a butterfly is the only way to protect time travel.
Butterflies are a sign of doom in time travel.
A small change in the past could affect the future greatly.
A butterfly is a symbol of how one changes when time traveling.

questions.question: What is suspension of disbelief?

choices.answer: Not believing anything in a story.
Setting aside our disbelief in order to believe the impossible.
Coming up with a lie that no one would ever believe.
Being easily persuaded to believe anything.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of foreshadowing in the story "The Martian"?

choices.answer: Tom does not want to go to town for Saturday evening.
Anna La Farge is afraid of the boy who arrives at their door in the rain.
Tom melts like wax as he changes to meet everyone's demands of him.
A neighbor relates the news about Nomland committing suicide.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT need our Suspension of Disbelief in the stories?

choices.answer: a Martian is able to shape-shift into deceased loved ones
an alarm system in a fully-automated house puts out a house fire
time travel to the prehistoric dinosaur age is possible
people have colonized Mars

questions.question: How is the Butterfly Effect demonstrated in the story "The Sound of Thunder"?

choices.answer: Eckles is surprised by his fear at the sight of the T-Rex.
The travel agency plans to punish anyone who does not follow the rules.
The men are not allowed to bring anything from the past into the present.
Eckles steps off the path and causes a change in the present government.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of personification from "There Will Come Soft Rains"?

choices.answer: The rain tapped on the empty house, echoing.
The house protectively draws up its shades in an old-maidenly preoccupation
The house's bared skeleton cringes from the fire's heat.
The water pump sighs and shrugs to a stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an onomatopoeia used in "There Will Come Soft Rains"?

choices.answer: The wires popped their sheathings.
The window shade snapped up.
The wires withered and the circuits cracked.
The voice-clock sang.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a metaphor from one of our Ray Bradbury stories?

choices.answer: The T-Rex's "flesh glittered like a thousand green coins."
"The sound [of the rifles] was lost in shriek and lizard thunder."
Hot water "whirled [toast] down a metal throat which digested" it...
"[Tom] was melting wax shaping to their minds."

questions.question: What is NOT an example of irony from the story "There Will Come Soft Rains"?

choices.answer: The "rain" that fell was not soft rain, but nuclear rain.
House sticks to a rigid schedule even after there is no one to follow it.
Humanity destroys itself and nature continues to live.
Humanity is responsible for creating the technology that destroys it.

questions.question: What is the common theme of the poem "There Will Come Soft Rains" by Sara Teasdale and Bradbury's short story?

choices.answer: People are killed in a war.
If humans destroy themselves in a war, nature won't care.
Nuclear rain is not soft.
War can destroy both mankind and the natural world.

questions.question: Which is NOT a theme regarding technology in "There Will Come Soft Rains"?

choices.answer: There is no evidence that humanity used technology to save itself.
Tech created to improve our lives also has its dangers.
Our love of new tech causes us not to see that tech is replacing us.
None of the four.

questions.question: Which is a theme regarding technology in "The Sound of Thunder"?

choices.answer: A small choice we make today could affect our future in a big way.
A time-travel company takes hunters on a safari in the dinosaur age.
Using technology without fully understanding its  consequence is foolish.
The travel agency warns customers to follow all rules to the letter.
